questions.question: Question 1: Which of the following criteria is diagnostic of acute kidney injury in a patient?

options.a: Rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days
options.b: Rise in creatinine  0.3mg/dl from baseline within 7 days
options.c: Rise in creatinine  0.5 mg/dl from baseline within 48 hours

questions.explanation:
719 
Sold by @itachibot A rise in creatinine 1.5 times the baseline value within 7 days is diagnostic of acute kidney injury 
(AKI). AKI is an abrupt decrease in kidney function within hours to days. According to the KDIGO 
definition, it is defined as any of the following: • Increase in serum creatinine by 0.3 mg/dL within 48 hours OR • Increase in serum creatinine to 1.5 times the baseline within 7 days OR • Urine volume <0.5 mL/kg/h for 6 hours.

questions.question: Question 2: AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify
questions.explanation:
AKIN and RIFLE criteria are used to classify acute kidney injury (AKI). The various classifications used in AKI are: • RIFLE criteria (Risk, Injury, Failure, Loss, End-stage) • AKIN (AKI Network) Classification • KDIGO (Kidney Disease Improving Global Outcomes) Classification RIFLE, AKIN, KDIGO definitions of AKI: RIFLE, AKIN, KDIGO staging of AKI: RIFLE

questions.question: Question 3: Patients with urine output below what level are said to have anuria?
questions.explanation:
Anuria is defined as urine output less than 100 mL/day. Oliguria is defined as urine output less 
than 400 mL/day. Acute kidney injury (AKI) can have varied clinical features depending on the etiology. The history 
and physical examination in AKI aims mainly at: • Finding the etiology • Identifying the occurrence of any complications The following clinical features may be seen: • Oliguria or anuria • Gross hematuria • Renal colic pain (in renal stones) • Loss of skin turgor, dry mouth, hypotension, tachycardia (in hypovolemia) • Prostatomegaly and/or a pelvic mass (in post-renal obstruction) • Dysuria, fever with chills and rigors, increased frequency of micturition, renal angle tenderness 
(in pyelonephritis) • Edema, hypertension (volume overload) • Encephalopathy, seizures, platelet dysfunction (uremia)

questions.question: Question 4: Which of the following causes prerenal AKI?
questions.explanation:
NSAIDs, Rhabdomyolysis and ACE inhibitors cause prerenal acute kidney injury (AKI). The use of NSAIDs causes reduced production of vasodilatory prostaglandins. This leads to 
decreased renal perfusion and glomerular capillary pressure. NSAIDs can also lead to acute 
interstitial nephritis, a cause of renal AKI. However, this is relatively uncommon. ACE inhibitors cause inhibition of efferent arteriole vasoconstriction, leading to reduced renal 
perfusion. Rhabdomyolysis causes AKI by both prerenal mechanisms (due to volume sequestration) and ATN 
(due to precipitation of myoglobin in the renal tubules). Nephrotoxins like myeloma light chains, snake venom, myoglobin (due to rhabdomyolysis) cause 
acute tubular necrosis (ATN). This leads to renal or intrinsic AKI. 721 
Sold by @itachibot

questions.question:
Question 5: A 48-year-old woman presented with severe abdominal pain, vomiting, and dark-coloured 
urine for the past 3 days. She has been on a combination painkiller for rheumatoid arthritis 
for 10 years. On examination, severe pallor was noted and BP was 180/120 mmHg. CT 
abdomen is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and CT scan showing papillary calcifications are highly suggestive of chronic 
kidney disease caused by analgesic nephropathy. This condition is more common in females secondary to excessive prolonged use of a combination 
of analgesics. The mechanism of injury is medullary hypoxia leading to papillary necrosis and 
finally causes chronic tubulointerstitial nephritis. Patients can remain asymptomatic for a long time. Sloughing or obstruction of papillae can cause 
abdominal pain and hematuria. It increases the risk of urothelial malignancies. The following CT 
findings can be seen: • Papillary calcifications • Small kidneys • Irregular contour Note: NSAID-induced nephropathy causes acute interstitial nephritis. It is a type IV 
hypersensitivity reaction. The features include non-oliguric AKI, fractional excretion of sodium 
(FeNa) < 1, and hyperkalemia. It is seen within a few days of use and is reversible. The image below shows papillary calcifications: 722 
Sold by @itachibot The given image shows papillary calcification on ultrasonography:

questions.question:
Question 6: A 38-year-old woman presents with nausea, vomiting, fatigue, and oliguria for the past three 
days. On further investigation, urine osmolality was 800 mOsm/kg, urinary sodium 10 meq/L, 
and BUN: creatinine ratio was 20:1. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is highly suggestive of prerenal AKI based on the following: • Urine osmolality >500 mOsm/kg • Urinary sodium < 20 meq/l • BUN: Creatinine ratio of 20:1 Differences between prerenal, and renal AKI: 723

questions.question:
Question 7: A 35-year-old man was admitted following a crush injury to his left leg. Two days later, his 
urine/plasma creatinine levels are < 20. What is the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
This clinical scenario and urine/ plasma creatinine ratio of <20 is suggestive of renal AKI due to 
rhabdomyolysis-induced acute tubular necrosis. Rhabdomyolysis is a serious complication of crush injuries. It leads to muscle breakdown, 
releasing a high amount of myoglobin in the blood. Myoglobinuria can lead to acute kidney 
injury by the following mechanisms: • Direct toxic effect of myoglobin and heme on the PCT • Tubular obstruction by precipitation of pigmented casts • Renal vasoconstriction can cause FeNa < 1 (unlike other renal causes of AKI) Indices

questions.question:
Question 8: A 38-year old woman presents with severe muscle pain and high-coloured urine for the past 3 
days. She joined a gym 2 weeks ago and has been strenuously working out. She was 
diagnosed with hypothyroidism 8 years back. Work-up reveals high serum creatine kinase, 
uric acid, and creatinine. Which of the following is likely to be present in this patient?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis. Hypocalcemia is seen in this 
condition. The causes of rhabdomyolysis include: • Hypothyroidism (precipitated by exertion, alcohol, infection) • Crush injury • Electric shock • Prolonged seizures • Malignant hyperthermia • Exertion • Drugs like fibrates, statins • Polymyositis / Dermatomyositis • McArdle's disease (GSD-5) causes recurrent rhabdomyolysis. Patients often present with muscle pain and high-colored urine. The following features are seen: • High serum CK (> 5 times normal) • High serum myoglobin • High serum LDH • Hyperkalemia • Hypermagnesemia • Hyperphosphatemia • Hypocalcemia 725 
Sold by @itachibot • Hyperuricemia • Once AKI develops, high serum creatinine and urea The treatment includes administration of large amounts of IV fluids (5-6 liters), alkalization of 
urine, and hemodialysis.

questions.question:
Question 9: A 54-year-old man presented with reduced urine output, swelling of his feet, and eyelid 
puffiness for 1 week. He also complains of back pain for the past 3 months, unresponsive to 
painkillers. Investigations reveal the following. What is the possible cause of renal failure in 
this patient?
questions.explanation:
Bence-Jones proteins on urine analysis are suggestive of multiple myeloma. It causes acute kidney 
injury (AKI) by the following mechanisms: • Hypercalcemia - leads to intense renal vasoconstriction and reduced perfusion • Myeloma light chains - cause direct tubular toxicity.

questions.question: Question 10: Non-oliguric renal failure may be seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
questions.explanation:
Non-oliguric renal failure may be seen in the following conditions: • Acute interstitial nephritis • Acute tubular necrosis (aminoglycoside toxicity, contrast-induced nephropathy) All the causes of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) cause non-oliguric AKI except acyclovir (oliguric 
AKI). The difference in urine output between oliguric and non-oliguric AKI may be due to variations in 
GFR or in the rate of tubular reabsorption. Non-oliguric forms may be associated with less severe 
injury. Other options: Prerenal causes such as congestive heart failure cause oliguric AKI. In 
post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, oliguria occurs as a result of decreased GFR.

questions.question:
Question 11: A 47-year-old electrician was rushed to the hospital following an electrical shock. 
Examination reveals electrical burns. During the course of treatment, he developed an 
arrhythmia and was managed appropriately. What arterial blood gas finding would you 
expect in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Electrical burns result in rhabdomyolysis. It presents with hyperkalemic metabolic acidosis. Muscle breakdown in rhabdomyolysis leads to hyperkalemia which causes arrhythmias. It also 
causes high anion gap metabolic acidosis due to the increase in H+ ions and liberation of organic 
anions.

questions.question:
Question 12: A patient with acute renal failure was found to have metabolic acidosis on evaluation. What is 
the likely cause?
questions.explanation:
In acute renal failure, metabolic acidosis occurs due to decreased excretion of ammonium. This 
impairs the excretion of H+ ions as NH4 ions. 726 
Sold by @itachibot Normally, H+ are excreted via the kidney in combination with ammonia which acts as a urinary 
buffer. In AKI, there is a decreased capacity of tubules to secrete ammonia. Due to reduced amounts of 
ammonia, the production of NH4 is impaired. Hence, H+ ions cannot be excreted, which leads to 
metabolic acidosis.

questions.question:
Question 13: A 75-year-old obese woman, who is a known diabetic presented with chest pain. Coronary 
angiography was done. Her S.creatinine levels before and after the procedure are given below. 
Which of the following is not a risk factor for the complication she developed?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario shows >0.5 mg/dL increase in S.creatinine levels, which is indicative 
of contrast-induced nephropathy for which obesity is not a risk factor. Contrast-induced nephropathy is defined as a 25% or 0.5 mg/dL increase from the baseline value 
of serum creatinine within 48-72 hours of intravenous contrast administration. It occurs due to 
tubular damage and as a result, the patient develops non-oliguric transient nephropathy. Risk factors for contrast medium-induced nephropathy: Patient-related: • eGFR < 60 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intra-arterial administration • eGFR < 45 mL/min/1.73 m2 before intravenous administration • Patient conditions that increase the risk: • Diabetic nephropathy • Dehydration • Congestive heart failure (NYHA grade 3–4) and low LVEF • Recent myocardial infarction (<24 h) • Intra-aortic balloon pump • Peri-procedural hypotension • Low hematocrit level • Age over 70 • Concurrent administration of nephrotoxic drugs • Known or suspected acute renal failure Procedure-related: • Intra-arterial administration of contrast medium • High-osmolality agents • Large doses of contrast medium • Multiple contrast medium administrations within a few days Side effects of iodinated contrast material include: • Idiosyncratic anaphylactoid reaction - patient develops bronchospasm and hypotension 727 
Sold by @itachibot • Dose-dependent side effect – contrast-induced nephropathy seen especially with the use of high 
osmolar agents Prevention of contrast-induced nephropathy: • IV fluids (isotonic saline or sodium bicarbonate) started 1 hour before and continued for at least 
3-6 hours after the procedure • Low volume low osmolar contrast should be used • N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure

questions.question: Question 14: Which of the following is false regarding contrast-induced nephropathy?

options.d: Hypoxia due to nephrotoxic agents is the cause

questions.explanation:
Dialysis-requiring AKI is uncommon in contrast-induced nephropathy. Contrast-induced AKI is generally associated with the use of high osmolar contrasts such as: • Iodinated contrast agents • High-dose gadolinium Mechanism of contrast-induced injury includes: • Medullary ischemia and hypoxia: By inducing intense vasoconstriction • Toxic tubular damage: By direct injury It usually develops within 24-48 hrs. Serum creatinine peaks by 3-5 days and normalizes by 7-10 
days. It manifests mainly as a non-oliguric renal failure and has an excellent prognosis. Contrast-induced AKI can be prevented by: • Use of iso-osmolar or non-ionic contrast agents (least toxic) • Administering minimum required quantity of contrast • Pre- and post-hydration (IV normal saline 1 mL/kg/h x 12 h prior and post-exposure) • N-acetyl cysteine may be given prior to contrast exposure.

questions.question: Question 15: Which of the following is not a marker of kidney injury?
questions.explanation:
Acid phosphatase is not a marker of kidney injury. The various markers of kidney injury are as follows: • IL-18 • Cystatin C • NGAL (neutrophil gelatinase-associated lipocalin) • KIM-1 (kidney injury molecule-1) • LFABP (liver fatty acid-binding protein) • 728 
Sold by @itachibot • NHE3 (sodium hydrogen exchanger 3) • NAG (N-acetyl glucosaminidase) • Alanine aminopeptidase • Osteopontin • ALP

questions.question:
Question 16: Which intravenous fluid is preferred for the hydration of patients with pre-renal acute kidney 
injury?
questions.explanation:
Isotonic crystalloids like 0.9% NaCl are preferred for the correction of hypovolemia in pre-renal 
AKI. Management of AKI: 1. AKI care bundle: • Nephrotoxic drugs should be avoided and the dosage of other drugs must be adjusted according 
to kidney function • Creatinine levels and urine output must be closely monitored 2. Hemodynamic management: • If hypovolemic - fluid replenishment using isotonic crystalloids (normal saline) • If euvolemic - fluid intake = urine output + additional ~500 mL • If hypervolemic - diuretics are administered. If the response is unsatisfactory, dialysis is 
required. 3. Management of complications: • Pulmonary edema - Treated with diuretics, non-invasive ventilation, and dialysis if refractory • Metabolic acidosis - Treated when pH <7.2 with oral or IV sodium bicarbonate • Hyperkalemia - Treated by restriction of dietary potassium, administration of sodium 
polystyrene sulfonate, insulin, glucose, inhaled -agonist, and calcium gluconate Options A and B: Hydroxyethyl starch solutions and dextrans increase the risk of severe AKI and 
are contraindicated. Option D: Ringer's lactate is preferred only when a large volume of fluids is required.

questions.question:
Question 17: Continuous renal replacement therapy is preferred in patients with which of the following 
features?
questions.explanation:
Continuous renal replacement therapy (CRRT) is a modality of dialysis that involves hemodialysis 
and hemofiltration. It is the preferred option in AKI patients with severe hypotension. It is preferred in the following cases: • Acute renal failure complicated by hemodynamic instability or heart failure • Severe volume overload unresponsive to diuretic therapy 729 
Sold by @itachibot • Brain edema • Hypercatabolism state • Acute or chronic liver failure as a renal support measure It is an extracorporeal blood purification therapy intended to substitute for impaired renal 
function over an extended period of time, aimed at being applied for 24 hours a day. There is 
no rapid shift of volume and osmolarity with this process as in intermittent hemodialysis. The other types of dialysis are: • Intermittent hemodialysis - may be done in hemodynamically stable patients with AKI • Peritoneal dialysis - used when hemodialysis is not available.

questions.question: Question 18: Which of the following is not seen in tumor lysis syndrome?

options.a: Tunneled catheters are associated with lower infection rates
options.b: Access of choice is radiocephalic arteriovenous fistula
options.c: Glutaraldehyde is used as a reprocessing agent
options.d: Urea is cleared more efficiently than creatinine

questions.explanation:
Hypocalcemia, not hypercalcemia, is seen in tumor lysis syndrome (TLS). TLS is a potentially life-threatening condition characterized by the rapid destruction of a large 
number of tumor cells. The release of calcium phosphate from lysed cells contributes to 
hyperphosphatemia and subsequent reciprocal depression in serum calcium levels. The 
consumption of ionized calcium during the formation of calcium phosphate crystals leads to 
hypocalcemia. TLS is commonly observed after initiation of chemotherapy in hematologic malignancies 
characterized by high cell turnover rates, such as Burkitt's lymphoma and acute lymphoblastic 
leukemia. The destruction of neoplastic cells results in the release of nucleic acids, which are broken down 
into uric acid, leading to hyperuricemia. The acidic environment in the renal tubules can cause 
uric acid to precipitate, leading to acute renal failure. Potassium is released in large quantities 
during tumor cell lysis leading to hyperkalemia. TLS is diagnosed using the Cairo-Bishop criteria which includes both laboratory and clinical 
criteria. Prevention is the mainstay of the management of TLS, which involves includes allopurinol, which 
inhibits the production of uric acid, and aggressive hydration to promote urine flow. Urinary 
alkalization is not recommended. Febuxostat, a selective xanthine oxidase inhibitor, can be used 
as an alternative. In severe cases or when renal failure is present, rasburicase, a recombinant urate oxidase, is used 
for treatment. Rasburicase rapidly lowers uric acid levels by converting it into a highly soluble 
compound called allantoin. Renal replacement therapy is often required and should be considered 
in case of acute renal failure. 730 
Sold by @itachibot Renal Replacement Therapy
